pages.text: Pseudonaraoia hammanni comes from the Middle Ordovician, with fossils found in the Maotianshan Shales, China. It is a small naraoiid, growing up to 1.75 cm in length. They had flat semi-circular cephalons that bore no compound eyes on the top, and a elongated pygidium, both of which bore spines.

The generic names derive from the Latin word 'pseudes', to mean 'false'; and the Latinised place name of 'Narao', a group of small lakes in Canada, near to where some of the first fossils of naraoiids were found. The specific name derives from the Latinised surname of Dr. Wolfgang Hammann, a German palaeontologist who studied both trilobites and naraoiids.
